meanings.definition: To be half asleep; doze intermittently.
meanings.sent1: After a long day of playing outside, the tired child started to drowse on the couch.
meanings.sent2: The cat would often drowse in the warm sunbeam coming through the window.
meanings.sent3: As the boring lecture droned on, the students began to drowse in their seats.
meanings.sent4: The gentle rocking of the boat made me drowse off into a peaceful nap.
meanings.sent5: The soothing sound of rain outside made it easy for me to drowse into a relaxed state.

meanings.sent1: The drowse that lingered after waking up made it hard to get out of bed.
meanings.sent2: She felt a pleasant drowse settle over her as she lay in the hammock.
meanings.sent3: The drowse of the lazy Sunday afternoon made time seem to slow down.
meanings.sent4: The drowse of the warm summer day made everything feel hazy and dreamlike.
meanings.sent5: The drowse of the cozy cabin enveloped us in a sense of calm and contentment.
